No fue hasta que se caso con Isaac, un productor de café que fue quien la animó a que retomara la producción de este cultivo así que alternando con las labores del hogar y con la ayuda de su esposo e hijos trabajan diariamente en sus fincas para salir adelante como familia. Anteriormente producían café convencional, pero gracias a la asesoría del personal de la “Unión Regional de Huatusco” han realizado las acciones necesarias para que su producción sea en su totalidad de café orgánico pues es mejor pagado en el mercado y no daña al medio ambiente ya que no utiliza fertilizantes químicos. Paulina y su esposo tienen como meta aumentar su producción la cual fue de 6 toneladas durante la última cosecha y saben que si siembran más planta y compran fertilizante en 2 años estarán produciendo 8 toneladas. También necesitan hacer labores de limpieza para obtener mejores resultados. Para llevar a cabo estas acciones necesitan un crédito pues no cuentan con el recurso económico suficiente para invertir en su finca. Como meta personal en unos meses planean abrir un pequeño negocio de abarrotes en su casa para que de esta manera puedan aumentar sus ingresos.
texts.en: Paulina learned coffee farming from her father when she was just a girl.  She left farming for several years and it was only when she married her husband, Isaac, a coffee farmer, that she decided to pick up where she left off.  She still runs her household, but she spends the rest of her time on the farm, working to provide for her family.  She used to grow coffee the convential way but thanks to advice from the team at "Union Regional de Huatusco", she now knows how to grow coffee organically.  She only grows organic coffee now and says that it fetches a better price at market and is better for the environment.  Paulina and her husband produced 6 tons of coffee last year and they know that in 2 years--if they sow more plants and buy fertilizer--they'll be able to produce 8 tons.  They also need to prepare their land for the next crop to ensure a good yield.  Paulina is applying for a loan that she will use to buy the supplies she needs for the farm.  For the future, she wants to open a small grocery that she expects to generate an extra income for her family.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her farming business.

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is a single woman who lives in Kisauni, Mombasa. She works persistently in her own business there. She sells very fresh tropical fruits and vegetables at a high volume. She sells things like tomatoes, onions, carrots, cucumbers, beets, potatoes, melon, passion fruit, and everything that is produced in the harvest of each season.

Because of this, she wins over a lot more customers every day. Her goal for later on is to have her own house; this is her greatest dream. She works carefully every day, and that makes it very evident that everything she earns is invested in generating income. Lately, she has been selling cooked food, taking advantage of her three years as a merchant. She knows a lot about the public market where she is.

With this food selling business, she generates additional income, which increases her family’s well-being every day. However, she has insufficient working capital to meet her customers’ demand for fruit, vegetables, cheese, and whey.

That is the reason why she turns to a Kiva loan, her first loan with Yehu Microfinance. She will use the loan to buy wholesale fruits and vegetables. This will increase her working capital, and there will be enough profits produced by her Kiva loan to invest in her restaurant business. This promises to be successful because she does it within the framework of the market demand.

loans.use: to buy wholesale fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda  is  32 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. Rosalinda  has a food/retail shop or sari-sari store that buys & sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products & beverages. She had this business for seven  years. She requested a loan for  5,000 PHP  to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks & beverages. 

Rosalinda has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Rosalinda hopes to improve her business for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Mlongo

texts.en:
Mlongo is a woman of integrity who enjoys mingling with other people. She is quick to make friends and this has enabled her to attract many customers to her milk selling business. Mlongo sells both sour and fresh milk door to door. To earn additional income, Mlongo is engaged in farming. 

She is married to a responsible man who operates a motorcycle transportation business. He makes sure that his family lives happily despite his low monthly income. He and Mlongo are blessed with two boys and two girls. The first-born is in the fourth grade and the youngest is still a baby. The family lives in their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

Mlongo is requesting this loan in order to prepare her farm for planting and also to purchase more milk to offer for sale. Thanks to her efforts, she has been able to help sustain her family's needs.
 
Mlongo has been in her milk sales business for two years. Her dream is to open a shop in future. She is determined to work hard to ensure the timely repayment of her loan.

loans.use: to prepare her farmland for planting and to purchase milk to offer for sale

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
This is Leonila, 42, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is a single parent to her children and she is the only one raising her children. She manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Leonila operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also has a direct selling business for additional income. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Leonila is hoping to be able to expand soon and to increase the number of her loyal customers. She dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work in her business.  She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Anzhela

texts.en:
Anzhela lives in the town of Sisian with her husband and their 15-year old daughter. Anzhela and her husband are both involved in farming. They cultivate barley and potatoes on farmland located outside the town. 

Anzhela has applied for this loan in order to begin planning the cultivation of her potato crops. She plans to utilize the loan funds to purchase potato seeds, fertilizer, and fuel, all of which she plans to use for planting, cultivation, and eventual transportation of the harvest.

The rich harvest Anzhela hopes to obtain will allow her not only to sustain her family during this year, but will also bring in addiitonal income from the sale of the produce. She will invest this extra income in developing her agricultural efforts for next year.

loans.use: to pay for potato seeds, fertilizer, and fuel

loans.name: Meyoki

texts.en:
Meyoki is 48 years old and married. He supports a family of six children. He is a wheat and beans farmer and has been in this business for the last five years with a monthly income of KES 50,000. 

He is servicing his fourth loan of KES 50,000 from KADET LTD and this will facilitate him in preparation of the land and purchasing farm inputs.

He hopes to use anticipated profits to expand his farm and reinvest. His future dream is to improve the family's living standards and educate his children.

loans.use: to pay for land cultivation and buy  farm inputs.

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred is single and a very hardworking man who, since his early age, has done nothing more than work to help support his parents. He has sold charcoal for the last three years, purchased a cart to support the weight of the orders he’d get and gradually he’s been complementing his business. His goal is to continue his business growth and later on to get a commercial space to sell at wholesale as well as retail.

However, in the face of market demand and sales potential, his working capital is insufficient to reach his goals step by step, which is the reason he’s calling on a Kiva loan to pay cash for larger amounts of charcoal and buy a piece of land. His Kiva loan will be successful because Alfred knows his market and he’s backed up by demand for it. He will buy in volume and pay cash, which will lead to more price competitiveness because of the discounts his suppliers will give him this season.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal and a piece of land.

loans.name: Ayesha's Group

texts.en: Ayesha is a very hardworking woman. She takes care of her home very well and supports her family financially by sewing clothes. She is very talented. She can sew designer and non-designer clothes very easily. She has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah to buy an electric sewing machine to fulfill her client's orders in less time and improve the quality of her work. She has three children and her husband is a driver. Ayesha’s children couldn’t complete their basic education because of financial problems. But now she believes that taking a loan from Kiva partner Asasah will help her to earn money and change the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy an electric sewing machine

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe, age 42, sells beauty products from Natasha and Avon. She has run this business for five years. She is unmarried. 

She joined HSPFI earlier this year. She has requested a loan in the amount of PhP 8,000 in order to buy beauty products to offer her customers. These products will include face powder, makeup, facial cream, and facial cleansing foam.

In the future, Fe hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy beauty products to offer for sale to her customers

loans.name: Kanini

texts.en:
Kanini operates a vegetable stand where she sells sukumawiki, cabbages, tomatoes, etc. to the neighborhood and passersby. The stand, which she owns, is located outside her house along a busy street. Her ideal location offers great growth opportunity in her community. In addition, she operates a tailoring business.

Kanini is grateful to Yehu for recognizing her business’ potential and giving her the funds needed to get started. She says that without Yehu's help she doesn’t believe her business would be possible.

Down the road, Kanini would like to expand the size of her stand, as well as the variety of products she carries. Kanini believes this is an attainable goal because of her property’s size and says that when the time comes it can be done cost effectively.

She attributes the success she has had to the personal relationships she has developed with clients. When asked the secrets to success for a customer service-oriented business, Kanini lists creating a friendly, comfortable atmosphere where each customer is treated as an individual. She is applying for a loan of KES 20,000 in order to buy clothing materials and more stock of vegetables.

loans.use: to buy clothing materials and more stock of vegetables.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam, 40, is married with three girls and three boys. The first-born is in form three, while three others are in classes eight, five, and two. The other two are not yet enrolled in school. Mariam has been farming for several years, an activity she is still doing to complement her kiosk business, which she has run for the last six years.

Mariam’s husband is employed in a private company. Mariam is thankful to him for his hard work and commitment toward the welfare of his family. He makes sure that his family does not lack anything. Mariam narrates that she got her starting capital from her husband, and that enabled her to start this kiosk, selling very few commodities. She is now happy for her business, which has grown more than before. However, her challenge remains: she lacks enough capital to expand her business. This is why she is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings from Yehu through Kiva so as to add stock of wheat and maize flour. She will also use the loan to clear a fees balance for her form three son.

loans.use: to add stock of wheat and maize flour, and also clear a fees balance for her form three son.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is married and lives with her two children, both of whom attend school, in Kisauni, ten minutes away from Mombasa town. There she has her own business, where she makes fried foods and natural juices with tropical fruits, according to the season. Her market is located in the neighborhood where she lives and is aimed at serving the surrounding areas, where little by little she is becoming better known for the quality of the food and drinks she offers and for the freshness of her fruit and base ingredients, and also because her business is located across from a very popular fast food business operating in the area, which boosts her sales.

She needs to purchase input materials at a better price and in larger quantities, so that she can become more competitive. Actually, her working capital is her greatest challenge in achieving her productivity goal. This is why she is requesting a Kiva loan, which she will use to purchase oil, corn, sugar, salt, and other ingredients in cash and in larger quantities than usual.

Her Kiva loan will be a successful investment because it is aimed at increasing her business' productivity and competitive capability, so that she can gradually expand and generate a sustainable income that will provide for her young children's well-being. Her dream is to see them become successful professionals in the future.

loans.use: to purchase oil, corn, sugar, salt, and other ingredients

loans.name: Mukhtaran's Group

texts.en:
Mukhtaran has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for her husband who will buy iron and steel for making iron and steel boxes in larger quantity. This will help him improve his products and services and increase his income.

Mukhtaran has a lot of confidence in her husband. She is very hopeful that the loan will be a productive one for him and will increase his profits. She is a housewife, remaining at her home and doing her household responsibilities. She has 3 sons and a daughter. All of them remain at home and don’t do anything.

Mukhtaran is optimistic about her family’s better future after the investment of a loan into her husband’s business. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Mukhtaran.

loans.use: To buy iron for iron box making business

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana is from the town of Trinidad, Bohol. She has had a sari-sari (variety) store business for almost seven years. She sells snack foods, spices, toiletries, and rice to her community. She has a monthly income of 5000 PHP, which allows her to help her husband provide for their daily needs.

Juana is requesting a loan to buy more items to sell such as rice, soft drinks, and canned goods. She hopes for her business to improve and to be able to help those in need.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell such as rice, soft drinks, and canned goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a bale of jeans for resale.

loans.name: Florenly

texts.en:
Florenly is 23 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has two children.

Florenly sells snacks such as "suman" and "biko" in her local community.  She has had this business for four years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy raw ingredients, including flour, sugar, cheese, and margarine, to use in making snacks.

Florenly has been a member of HSPFI since 2012. In the future, she hopes to improve her business to support the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients to use in making snacks

loans.name: Vatha

texts.en:
Vantha is a 52-year-old widow with two independent children. One of her children works at a hotel while the other one works at a church. 

Vantha manages the family's hardship by growing Marian plums and jack-fruit as her primary source of income. She also sells clothes and works as the chief during weddings to earn additional income. Now, Vantha is seeking her second loan with Kiva's partner, VisionFund. The first loan, which she successfully paid back, has helped her to stabilize her businesses, especially by purchasing more clothes for resale. She is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to buy additional clothes for resale. She hopes that her business will greatly improve and she will earn more income.

loans.use: To buy additional clothes for resale

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline is a fish vendor. Her first Kiva loan was repaid promptly and on time, and her business is thriving. She has requested her second loan in the amount of KES. 60,000 in order to pay tuition fees for her child, who is a university student. 

She hopes to see her business continue to flourish so that she can help secure the education of all five of her children.

loans.use: to purchase fish to offer for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stock of canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Isabella

texts.en:
Isabella is 36 years old and is married to Bernard. They are blessed with three children aged 14, 11, and 4 years. She practices farming, which she ventured into three years ago, and earns a monthly income of 20,000 Kenyan shillings. 

She has requested a fourth loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings to buy 25 kilograms of maize seed and 5 bags of fertilizer. Her profit will help her purchase a piece of land to expand her farming. 

She hopes to educate her children to higher levels.

loans.use: To purchase 25 kg of maize seed and 5 bags of fertilizer.

loans.name: Mann

texts.en:
Mann, age 54, is a farmer in Baray district, where she grew up. She works the land with her husband, with whom she has seven children, two of whom are grown and married. Mann and her husband help each other in maintaining the farm work and providing the income to support the family. 

Recently, one of Mann’s daughters has become engaged to be married. Mann is now asking for a loan from HKL and Kiva in order to pay for the wedding expenses of her daughter, who is planning her wedding for the near future. 

Mann genuinely appreciates the continuous financial support available from Kiva lenders. This loan will provide sufficient funds for her to prepare her daughter’s wedding.

loans.use: to pay for the wedding expenses of her daughter

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah is 43 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has one child.

Leah sells products from Avon like beauty products and ready-to-wear cloths. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy more products from Avon like body lotion, make-up, and underwear.

Leah has been a member of HSPFI since 2012. In the future, she hopes to improve her business for the education of her child.

loans.use: to buy more products from Avon to resell.

loans.name: Mwanzanje

texts.en:
Mwanzanje, 42, lives in the village of Tiribe, Kenya. He is married and has a family of four. He works every day to make progress for his family. He operates a goat meat business in which he has worked for around two years, selling his animals to the slaughter houses.

Mwanzanje credits the loans from Yehu for the growth of his small business, because they have given him business capital. 

He is asking for a loan to buy more goats so that he can keep working and meeting his orders from his customers. He is grateful for the opportunity from Kiva and Yehu. Mwanzanje's dream is to open a retail shop in the near future.

loans.use: to buy more goats for resale

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Neema is married and has one child who is still too young for school. She works persistently in her own business in Kisauni, Mombasa. She sells very fresh tropical fruits and vegetables in large volume. She sells things like tomatoes, onions, carrots, cucumbers, beets, potatoes, melon, and passion fruit. Because of this she wins over many new customers every day. Her husband works as a mason and they have both managed to generate income to support their household. However, she has insufficient working capital to meet her customers’ demand for fruit and vegetables.

That is the reason why she has turned to a Kiva loan, her first loan with Yehu Microfinance. She will use the loan to buy wholesale fruits and vegetables. This will increase her working capital, and she will have enough profits to invest in cheese and whey. This promises to be successful because she does it within the framework of market demand. She knows her customers’ needs very well.

loans.use: to buy wholesale fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Baranabas

texts.en:
Baranabas is 32 years old and comes from Kisumu City, situated in the Western part of Kenya. He is married to Eunice who operates a food kiosk and they have three children aged eight, four and  one years.


He operates motorcycle transport business locally known as bodaboda; he has been  doing this transport  business for the last nine months and has been generating a monthly income of KES 7,000. At the moment, he is taking his third loan from KADET LTD which he will use buy spare parts for the motorbike. He will use his profits to sustain the family. 

His dream is to have a big motorcycle transport business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts.

loans.name: Phelister

texts.en:
Phelister used her previous loan to buy bundles of wheat flour, cooking oil, beans and maize flour. Today she is requesting a new loan to buy, wholesale and in cash, the vegetables, meat, and other supplies she needs to make the dishes she sells. This would allow her to have a stock of inventory, get discounts for quick payment, and offer a varied menu to her customers who have become accustomed to her delicious flavors every day.

Phelister hopes that through Kiva many  entrepreneurs will continue to get support so they can get ahead with their projects and improve their living conditions and those of their nuclear family: a message she wanted to give her lenders.

loans.use: to buy, wholesale and in cash, vegetables, meat, and other supplies

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is a married woman with a 13-year-old child. She lives in the town of San Miguel, Bohol with her family. Her husband is a carpenter.

Rosita started her sari-sari (variety) store business two year ago. She wanted to help her husband provide for their family's needs and sustain her child's education. She earns 6000 PHP per month selling soy sauce, vinegar, canned goods, soft drinks and other items. Rosita hopes for her income to increase and be able to save for her child's college education. She plans to use her loan to buy more items to sell such as soft drinks, canned goods and gasoline. This loan will help increase Rosita's sales and profitability.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell such as soft drinks, canned goods and gasoline

loans.name: Norafil

texts.en:
This is Norafil, who is 37 and a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is a mother to her children and is married to Elpidio, her business partner.  At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Norafil operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings where all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend on cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands costs less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments, and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Norafil dreams of being able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work. She also hopes to have her own food stall someday.  She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is 56 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has five children. Alma has a food shop, or sari-sari store, that sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products, and beverages. She has had this business for five years. 

Alma requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages.  She has been a member of HSPFI since 2012. In the future, she hopes to improve her business to support the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
Teodora, age 55, runs a sari-sari (general store) business where she buys and sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products, and beverages. She has operated this business for five years. Teodora and her husband have two children.

She joined HSPFI earlier this year and is requesting a loan in the amount of PhP 5,000 in order to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages to offer in her store. 

In the future, Teodora hopes to improve her business in order to secure the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages to offer for sale in her store

loans.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard has a motorcycle business in Nakuru town and has been in the business for the past year. He is 34 years old, married to Rachael, and they have two children. Besides the motorcycle business, he has a timber yard and carpentry business from which he's been able to make additional income to support his family. This is his first loan. He plans to buy more stock of timber for sale and thereby grow his timber yard business. In the future, Richard hopes to buy a plot and build a house for his family and also to own a showroom for displaying and selling carpentry furniture.

loans.use: to buy more timber for sale.

loans.name: Sogbandji Solange

texts.fr: Sogbandji Solange est mariée et mère de quatre enfants dont trois enfants scolarisés. Le plus âgé a 14 ans et le moins âgé a 04 ans. Elle a une baraque où elle vend du maïs, du gari, du mil et de l'haricot depuis quelques années et fait ses achats dans la sous région. Sa clientèle large et variée est essentiellement composée des semi grossistes et des détaillants. Sogbandji Solange avec ses économies veut participer à la scolarisation de ses enfants et assurer les soins médicaux adéquats pour ses enfants.
texts.en: Sogbandji Solange is married and mother to four children, three of whom attend school. The eldest of the children is 14 years old and the youngest four. She has a hut where she has been selling corn, gari (a spice), millet and beans for a few years, and she buys her goods in the sub-region. Her wide and diverse customer base is made up mainly of semi-wholesalers and retailers. Sogbandji Solange wants to contribute to her children's schooling with her savings and also provide for adequate healthcare for them.

loans.use: to buy 10 sacks of corn, I sack of gari, one sack of millet and one sack of beans.

loans.name: Rosemary Enole

texts.en:
Rosemary sells cereals and grocery items in her store. She has operated this business for the past 15 years in the Narok area and earns a good income. This will be her third loan from KADET Ltd. 

With her loan funds in the amount of KES 100,000, she intends to purchase maize and beans to offer for sale in her store, as well as to expand her business.


She intends to use the profits gained to reinvest and grow the business. Her future plans is to become a large scale outlet

loans.use: to buy a stock of maize and beans to offer for sale in her store

loans.name: Conception

texts.en:
Conception is 54 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 10 children. 

Conception is selling fish in the local community. She has had this business for six years. She requested a loan for 6,000 Philippine pesos to buy a variety of fish like sardines and milk fish to sell.

Conception became a member of HSPFI this year. In the future, Conception hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy stock of fish to sell

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka earns a living by selling maize and mats at the market. She has operated this business for three years. She and her husband live in Tiribe, Kenya, and have seven children, four of whom are enrolled in school. Her husband is a farmer who sells his farm produce at the market. He is a responsible father who is devoted to sustaining his family's needs. Mwaka tells us that she assists her husband in his farming activities when she finishes her selling activity at market. 

Mwaka works hard to increase her income and help to support her family. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase a stock of maize and also to buy more mats to offer for sale. 

Mwaka hopes for her business to thrive so that she can help to improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of maize and also to buy more mats to offer for sale

loans.name: Simforiana

texts.en: Simforiana lives in the town of Trinidad, Bohol with her family. She is married and has six children who are aged between 6 and 23 years. Simforiana and her husband are both farmers. They own land that they cultivate to grow rice for consumption and selling. Simforiana works hard to take care of her children and help her husband manage their rice farm. She has requested a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers, and to pay for labor. Simforiana hopes for her family's standard of living to improve in the future.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers, and to pay for labor

loans.name: Enrique

texts.es: Los comienzos de Enrique como cafetalero fueron cuando de joven empezó a trabajar como cortador para otros productores y fue allí donde aprendió a realizar todas las labores que se requieren para la producción del café. Cuando Enrique se casó con Matilde su padre le heredó un terreno para que comenzara a trabajarlo y producir su propio café para que de esta forma pudiera tener ingresos para su nueva familia. Ellos tienen actualmente 7 hijos los cuales les ayudan tanto en las labores del campo como del hogar. Enrique y su familia están produciendo actualmente un promedio de 6 toneladas por año las cuales venden en su totalidad a la “Unión Regional de Huatusco” para que sea posteriormente exportada. Para la siguiente cosecha Enrique necesita fertilizar su parcela para mantener el nivel de producción que lleva hasta ahora y por eso solicita un crédito. En un futuro a Enrique y su esposa planean poner una tienda de abarrotes en su casa para de esta forma tener más ingresos para su familia y así darles mayores comodidades y la posibilidad de que sus hijos se preparen mejor.
texts.en: Enrique started out in coffee growing when he was a young man and used to work as a cutter for other producers.  This was where he learned how to carry out all the tasks that are necessary in producing coffee.  When Enrique married Matilde, his father gave him a plot of land so that he could start working it and producing his own coffee in order to make income for his new family.  Enrique and his wife currently have seven children who help them with both their farm work and the housework.  Enrique and his family are currently producing an average of 6 tons of coffee a year and they sell all of it to the “Unión Regional de Huatusco” so that it can then be exported.  Enrique needs to fertilize his plot of land before his next harvest so that he can maintain the level of production he has enjoyed up to now.  This is why he is requesting a loan.  In the future, Enrique and his wife plan to set up a grocery store in their home so that they can make more income for their family, provide them with greater comfort, and better prepare their children.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
This is Fe, 56, a resident of Manila in the Philippines. She is married to Reymundo, a sidecar driver, and she is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Fe maintains a piggery business. She earns money by selling live hogs to meat dealers. Sometimes they have the pigs slaughtered and sold in the market.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 5,000 Philippine pesos in sales every week.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a loan of 30,000 pesos. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional hogs and feed needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Fe hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes to support her children's schooling up to college level. She also hopes to have her house renovated. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. At these meetings, she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies of feed and hogs needed in her business.

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah is a 26-year-old business man. He is married to Judith who is a business lady. They are blessed with one child. He has been operating a motorcycle transportation business for the past two years with a monthly income of KES 9,000, which he uses to support his family. 

He is applying for his third loan from KADET LTD after repaying the previous loans successfully. Elijah will use the loan to buy a heifer and animal feed. With the anticipated profit from the business, he will educate his child. 

His hopes and dreams are to venture into a mixed crop farming business and improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: to buy a heifer and animal feed.

loans.name: Tak

texts.en:
Tak is a resident living in a suburban area about 15 km from Phnom Penh city. She is 67 years old and a widowed woman who is responsible for two children. They are both married and live independently. Tak, even at her age, still works hard to generate income for her livelihood. She has been rice farming for ages and earns approximately $5.00 US per day. Tak has some of her children help her with the business in the rainy season. 

Tak would like to purchase an additional cow for her farm but, due to shortage of funds, she is asking for a loan of $700 US through HKL. She believes that it will help her achieve a good outcome for her business. Also, Tak will keep this cow for breeding purposes so she can increase her yield and income in the following years.

loans.use: to purchase a cow for farm work.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph, age 24, is a barber. He operates a barber shop and earns additional income by selling kerosene. He is not yet married. He started these businesses a year ago and earns a monthly income of KES. 40,000. 

Joseph has requested his first loan in the amount of KES 30,000 in order to purchase more kerosene to offer for sale. He intends to use the anticipated profit to invest back into the business. 

He hopes to bring more financial stability to his life.

loans.use: to purchase kerosene to offer for sale

loans.name: Petronilla

texts.en:
Petronilla lives in Kisauni, Mombasa, Kenya. She works every day because her dream is to have a store that is well-known in her town. In order to do this, she sells products brought from Mombasa town, where she lives with her spouse. With this, she has managed to save and invest in another business that has provided the opportunity to generate new income. 

The lack of working capital in the face of Petronilla’s dreams are her biggest challenge. This is why she has turned to Kiva credit with her first loan with Yehu Microfinance. With her Kiva loan, she will buy and sell bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and cooking fat oil, which are in high demand. Her loan should be successful because her sales are based on customer orders. What she buys has a fast turnover, which causes her working capital to turn quickly and therefore increase her profits. Choosing good customers would increase the recovery of her capital and thereby her earnings.

loans.use: to buy and sell bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and cooking fat oil

loans.name: Nemuta

texts.en:
Nemuta is 27 years old and married. She supports a family of five children. She is a wheat farmer and has been in this business for the last five years with a monthly income of 50,000 Kenyan shillings. 

She is servicing her fifth loan of 90,000 shillings from KADET. This will help her in preparing the farm and purchasing inputs.

She hopes to use the anticipated profits to expand her farm and reinvest. Her future dreams are to improve the family's living standards and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more inputs for her farming

loans.name: Thuch's Group

texts.en: Thuch, 65, is a widow living in the Ek Phnom district of Battambang province. She has five children, but she needs to support only one child currently. To make a living, she has been selling dried fish and smoked fish for 10 years. This is the fourth loan cycle for Thuch with VisionFund. The past three loans that she completely repaid enabled her to gradually improve her living conditions. She has formed a group with another member who has joined VisionFund for the sixth time to apply for this new loan. As the group leader, she will use her portion of the loan to buy more dried fish and smoked fish for sale. With the requested loan, she hopes to earn more income from her current business for her children’s sake.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish and smoked fish for sale

loans.name: Joab

texts.en:
Joab is a 26-year-old man from Nyalenda in Kisumu, a town toward the western part of Kenya. He is married to Brenda and they have no children.

Joab operates a retail shop within the center and has been doing this business for a period of three years. His monthly income is 8,000 Kenyan shillings.

He is taking his first loan from KADET LTD. He will use the loan to add the stock that will add value to the business, bringing more profit. He will use the anticipated profit to increase the volume of his sales by ploughing profit back into the business. His hope and dream is to become a successful businessman in the society.

loans.use: To buy sugar, tea leaves, and match boxes to sell.

loans.name: Guillermo Alberto

texts.es:
Guillermo sigue dando su servicio de taxi, en la capital de Managua,  trabajo cansado, pero que ha ayudado para el bienestar de su familia, obteniendo buenas ganancias, ya que es propio su taxi. Cuenta con el apoyo económico de su esposa, ya que tiene un pequeño tramo de artesanía en un mercado.
Don Guillermo ah venido dando mantenimiento general a su vehículo, atreves de los financiamiento obtenidos en Afodenic, ya que anteriormente lo hacía por parte el revidado del auto y ahora con esta oportunidad lo hace general, teniendo un buen servicio y carrera  a sus clientes. Comprara con este nuevo préstamo: cuatro llantas, amortiguadores, punta flecha, batería, motor parabrisas, par de tijeras y mano de obra.
texts.en:
Guillermo continues providing a taxi service in the capital city, Managua.  His work is tiring but it has helped him to provide for his family and he earns good profits because he owns his own taxi.  He has the financial support of his wife who has a small sales spot in a market where she sells handicrafts. 

Guillermo has been paying for general maintenance work to be carried out on his vehicle through loans from Afodenic.  In the past he used to have the work carried out in stages but now, with this opportunity, he is able to have everything done at once.  This allows him to provide his customers with a good service and a safe journey.  He will use this new loan to buy four tires, shock absorbers, bolts, a battery and a window motor.  He will also pay labor costs.

loans.use: to buy four tires and have maintenance work carried out on his taxi

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent, age 31, operates a food kiosk. She has operated this business for a period of three years and makes a monthly profit of KES 5,000. She and her husband Hillary have two children, ages six and 13 years old.

She is currently requesting her third loan from KADET Ltd. She will use the loan to purchase a stock of vegetables to offer for sale. The profit expected from the business will be used primarily to pay her children's school fees.

Her dream is to become successful in the field of small-scale business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of vegetables to offer for sale

loans.name: Bijuma

texts.en: Because of the need to generate income so that she could improve her family’s well-being, Bijuma began her business selling fish. Bijuma is a married woman who lives with her husband and two children. Her main clients are established merchant workers located around her home, from whom she receives payments every two weeks, according to their agreements. Bijuma is requesting a first loan through Yehu Microfinance trust, an organization she has been a part of for four months and that made it possible for her to set up her business, in order to give it a more comfortable environment. She will use the money from her first Kiva loan to buy supplies of fish in large quantities in order to increase the opportunities in the market, such as responding to new customers that have been referred by the current buyers and those whose attention she wants to capture with which she will buy supplies in quantities, which will allow her to buy at a discount for cash and large volume. She will pass these savings onto her customers, making her prices more competitive. This is what the Kiva loan will allow, a successful investment. Bijuma and her husband are very satisfied because working independently they have been able to provide for their children’s education and they dream of watching them become successful because they are definitely the engine of their lives.

loans.use: to buy supplies of fish in large quantities

loans.name: Aysama

texts.en:
Aysama is a 27-year-old married woman. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) and lives with her family in an IDP Settlement. She is farmer and raising seasonal fruits and vegetables. She has 5 years of experience in this field, which makes her an experienced and skilled person in this field. 

Aysama usually sells her crop in the central bazaar. People use fresh vegetables everyday and consider them healthy; many national dishes are made of vegetable, like pilau and dolma. Fresh fruits are served on every table in Azerbaijan families and also make fresh punch.  Her monthly income is 60 AZN. Raising crops takes a lot of strength and working in the open air, which is very hard for a woman and that is why her spouse helps her. 

She needs additional capital to invest in seeds and fertilizers. This will allow her to improve the quality of products she raises and increase her monthly turnover.  For this purpose she applied for 500 AZN.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s used-clothes selling business. With the loan investment, he will buy used clothes in larger quantities, which will allow him to offer a larger variety of used clothes to his customers, thus increasing his sales and his profits. He has been operating his business for many years, and the demand for his used clothes is very high, particularly amongst lower middle-class people.

Razia is confident that her husband will successfully bring his business to the next level, increase his income, and improve the family's standard of living.

loans.use: to buy a supply of used clothes to offer for sale

loans.name: Oruj

texts.en:
Oruj is a 48-year-old man who is married with four children. He is an IDP (internally displaced person). His business is car repair and he has more than 20 years of experience. His son helps him and learns how to repair cars. He usually repairs trucks and tractors, which there are more of in the settlement where he lives. His monthly income is 90 AZN. He is on a pension, which is very small, so car repair is the main source of income in his family. 

He applied for a loan of 1,500 AZN to purchase new car repair tools. This will be his second loan and he has a good client history.

loans.use: to buy new car repair tools

loans.name: Bahruz

texts.en:
Bahruz is a 28-year-old married man with two daughters. He is an IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with his family in Bilasuvar IDP Settlement.   He breeds sheep for meat and fur purposes and sells them to local butchers. Bahruz has more than 5 years of experience in this field, thanks to his father who taught him the best of how to look after sheep. He receives 90 AZN of financial support from the government monthly, but this is too low to cover family needs.

Bahruz usually buys lambs, raises and fattens them and resells them in 4-5 months at a more profitable price in the local livestock bazaar.  His monthly income is 110 AZN. People use meat in everyday national dishes as pilau and dolma and always use yogurt sauce. Mutton is considered as very healthy and is also present in everyday life. Fur is very useful for blankets and bed mattresses made by local woman.    

This is the only source of income for his family.  Bahruz applied for 1000 AZN to purchase 12 sheep and fodder. This will be his third loan and he has good credit history.

loans.use: to buy 12 sheep and fodder

loans.name: Phlang

texts.en:
Phlang is a hardworking father dedicated to a construction business, living with his family in a house located in Baray district, Kompong Tom province. Phlang is now 46 years old and married with three single children attending school. Recently, Phlang has been renovating his house and building rooms made of bricks on the ground floor. Phlang plans to rent the rooms to local teachers and students to start their part-time classes. This will give him a good return in the future.

Phlang needs more bricks and cement to finish this construction, so he is asking for a loan of US$1,100 to supplement his capital to purchase 15,000 bricks and 150 bags of cement. He hopes that he will be able to increase his household income and satisfy his living needs.

loans.use: to purchase 15,000 bricks and 150 bags of cement.

loans.name: Syprose

texts.en:
Syprose is a 38-year-old woman from Nyalenda, Kisumu. She is married to James and they have four children who are 18, 14, 11, and 4 years old.

Syprose does embroidery and tailoring. She has been operating the business for six years and her monthly income is 7,000 Kenyan shillings. She is taking her first loan from KADET LTD. She will use the loan to purchase more textile materials for the business. She will use the anticipated profit to pay school fees.

Her dream is to be successful in the business.

loans.use: To buy textile materials for her embroidery and tailoring business.

loans.name: Qafar

texts.en:
Qafar is a 35 years old man, married with two children. He is an IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with his family in Bilasuvar IDP settlement.   He breeds cows and cattle, and sells milk and milk products as well as cattle for meat purposes to local butchers. Qafar has more than 10 years of experience in this field, thanks to his father who taught him the best way to look after cattle.

Qafar usually buys small cattle, raises and fattens them in 5 to 6 months, and then resells them for a more profitable price in the local livestock bazaar.  He sells milk and yoghurt to the neighbors. Milk and meat selling brings an income of  90 AZN per month. Milk and yoghurt, as well as meat, are very popular products in Azerbaijan. People use meat in everyday national dishes such as pilau and dolma and always use yoghurt sauce. Milk products are considered to be very healthy and are also present in everyday life.   

This is the only financial income in his family and it is not enough to cover the basic needs of his beloved children. Qafar has applied for 1000 AZN to purchase one milking cow and fodder.

loans.use: to buy one milking cow and fodder.

loans.name: Munawar's Group

texts.en:
Munawar has a sewing and embroidery business. She sews clothes and does embroidery for her neighboring clients. She learned the art of sewing and embroidery from her mother before her marriage, and now she applies her skills toward earning profits to help support her family. Her husband has a construction supply business. They have two sons. The eldest is a car mechanic and the youngest is enrolled in the tenth grade at school.

Munawar has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her sewing and embroidery business. With the loan investment, she will buy clothes and embroidery material in bulk quantities. This will allow her to improve the quality and quantity of her work and to increase her income.
She has been operating her business for many years and is confident that her business will become more successful after the investment of this loan.

In the photo, the lady holding a book (called an Asasah Passbook) is Munawar.

loans.use: to buy clothes and embroidery material for her sewing and embriodery business

loans.name: Imomali

texts.ru: Имомали проживает в районе Рудаки. Ему 58 лет. Она вдовец. У него двое детей. Имомали занимается торговлей мяса. Он разводит мелко - рогатый и крупнорогатый скот в дальнейшем для продажи на мясо. В этой области он восемь лет. Кредит берет для закупа овец и коз.
texts.en: Imomali lives in Rudaki. He is 58 years old, a widower, and has two children. Imomali sells meat. He raises sheep, goats, and cattle and sells them later on for meat. He has been in this business for eight years. He is requesting a loan to buy sheep and goats.

loans.use: to buy sheep and goats

loans.name: Ng'anzuki

texts.en:
Ng'anzuki is taking out another loan to expand on her existing business of selling maize. She tells us that the previous loan enabled her to establish a stall at a strategic place at the market where she is selling her maize from. Thanks for the support given, she can now purchase a bigger quantity of maize for sale which he has managed to satisfy her customer needs.

Ng'anzuki aims to open a cereal shop in the near future. Her customers describe her as a lady who is easy to make friends with; kind and also caring. The profits she has gotten have helped her pay for the school fees for her children. The loan will be used to purchase more stock of maize for sale.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of maize for sale.

loans.name: Sharifa

texts.en:
Sharifa is 44 years old divorced woman who raises her two children alone. She is IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with her family in an IDP Settlement. She has 10 years of experience in poultry breeding. Her son helps her to breed poultry. 

Depending on the season different poultry is popular among Azerbaijani people. For instance chicken are popular throughout the year, goose and ducks in autumn and winter, and turkey in winter and spring. Hence, Sharifa breeds the most popular poultry for the particular season. Her monthly income is 130 ANZ. Her son helps to look after poultry. Demand for fresh poultry meat is very popular because people in Azerbaijan use it in many popular dishes.  

Sharifa would like to expand her business and purchase more poultry. For this purpose she applied for 1,000 AZN. This will be her second loan and she has good client history.

loans.use: to buy more poultry to increase income

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is married and lives in Kisauni, in the city of Mombasa. She is a salesperson and sells firewood to her neighbouring community members. She began her business in 2006 selling firewood and, little by little, she increased her stock due to her customers' demand. Mwanakombo’s sales are mainly cash down although she also sells on credit to some customers on a short-term basis depending on what they agree. 

Some time ago, Mwanakombo decided to take advantage of the market and began to sell charcoal. She has done very well and has been able to see her store grow. Her business is growing and she has to buy everything that her customers want, so it is a great challenge to her. This is why she needs a Kiva loan, her third loan through Yehu Microfinance. She will buy bundles of firewood and charcoal to be able to meet and satisfy the needs of her customers. Mwanakombo wants to have sales with special prices, since she will be able to buy in greater quantities and this will guarantee the success of her Kiva loan investment.

loans.use: To buy bundles of firewood and charcoal

loans.name: Batsaikhan

texts.en: Mr. Batsaikhan, 45, has been employed in a half-time job as an assistant worker in a manufacturing company. He lives with his wife in the ger (Mongolian felt housing tents) district, an area of the city with no running water, minimal roads and spotty electricity in Darkhan, the second largest city in Mongolia. He owns a small land plot and house, and he plants some kinds of vegetables in his backyard. Lately, his fence has been badly damaged due to the strong wind and its age. He decided to repair his fence. The loan he is taking will be dedicated to buying some wood and iron pipes to repair his fence.

loans.use: To buy some wood and iron pipes to repair his fence.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a married woman and owner of a fast food restaurant. After she finished her cooking classes, she decided to change jobs and dedicate her time to preparing and selling meals. She had an impact on the market with fried foods usually ordered by families. When she arrived in Kisauni she began to sell fast food. Today, she dreams of owning her own comfortable locale, where clients can find all of the delicious meals she knows how to prepare with love. 

Her job allows her to provide for her family’s well-being. Her family consists of two children who both attend school. She dreams of seeing them turn into successful people and they drive her life. At the moment she is requesting her first loan with Kiva and Yehu Microfinance Trust. She will use the loan to buy wholesale products in order to get discounts and offer competitive prices to her clients. This will help her to substantially raise her profits and have more clients so she can make more money to support her family.

loans.use: to buy wholesale products to prepare meals.

loans.name: Chamwino Group

texts.en:
Assa, who is in her early 40s, is married with three children. Two of them go to school and one has finished schooling. She has been a food vendor for five years now. She works from 1:00 to 4:00 (three hours only) and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be her sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to start building her house, pay school fees, and provide for household expenses. She has paid back her loan successfully. She wants a loan to buy wheat flour, sugar, cooking oil, beans, and charcoal. This will allow her to sell to more people. Her dream is to one day be able to build and finish her house.

Assa will share this loan with her loan group, Chamwino, which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, sugar, cooking oil, beans, and charcoal.

loans.name: Mussarat's Group

texts.en: Mussarat has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for her husband’s sewing machine manufacturing business. He has great technical skills and his sewing machines have high demand in the market. With the loan investment he will buy sewing machine spare parts in bulk quantity. This will help him complete larger orders on time and increase his profits. He has been operating his business for the past many years and Mussarat is very hopeful that the KIVA loan will be a more productive one for him.

loans.use: To buy sewing machine spare parts for her husband's sewing machine manufacturing business

loans.name: Tembo Mgwaza Group

texts.en: Aida, who is in her mid 40s, is married with three children who are still going to school. She has two businesses: selling bread door-to-door and growing vegetables to sell from her garden. She has had these businesses for two years now. She works from 7:00 am to 6:00 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. This will be her first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania which she wants to use to buy more bread to sell and to increase her garden space to grow and sell more vegetables. Her dream is to one day be able to finish building her house. Aida will share this loan with her loan group Tembo Mgwaza which has a total of 16 members. They will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more bread to resell and to increase her garden space to grow and sell more vegetables.

loans.name: Chinzorig

texts.en:
Mr. Chinzorig, 56, is a very neat and hardworking man. He runs a cafeteria in the downtown of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has been running his business for 2 years and during this time he has had many permanent customers. He lives with his wife, 46, and his son, 16, in the ger district, an area of the city with no running water, minimal roads and spotty electricity in Ulaanbaatar. 

Now he needs some money to make renovations and some repairs to his cafeteria hall. In the last years it never had any complete repair. The floor and some furniture have been bad and got old. Therefore he is requesting a loan to buy some building materials and cover the cost of hired workers. He had a plan of renovation before, but he could not do it due to the money shortage many times.

loans.use: To buy some building materials and cover the cost of hired workers.

loans.name: Koysinoy

texts.en: Koysinoy is a woman who likes to work very hard. She always tries to find new ways to make an income. She has a big family and that’s why she needs more money as she is the only breadwinner in her family. Koysinoy decided to organize her own business. She studied the sewing course of project ‘Start-up’ and now she is going to buy some sewing machines to organize her own business deal. She wants to work with her two daughters. Her daughters are also smart and hardworking. She believes that kind lenders will help and she’ll organize her business.

loans.use: To buy sewing machines

loans.name: Christ Roi 1 Group

texts.en:
Brice, age 42, is married with a 21-year-old child. He also provides and cares for his grandmother. Brice is representing the Christ Roi 1 group. He owns a grocery stand where he sells a variety of food products. He has had this business for over 15 years! His business strategy is to open early in the morning when many other stands are not open yet. He will use the loan to buy merchandise for his stand, including, sugar, soap, and drinks. 

Brice has received 4 previous loans from Kiva’s partner, HOPE Congo. He has a good repayment record. Brice hopes to build an actual building for his business one day. He also wants to use his profits to help his child study at a university.

loans.use: to pay for milk, sugar, and soap

loans.name: Norma Adilia

texts.es:
Doña Norma sigue en su pequeña venta de cajeta, lava, plancha, siempre activa y ayudando a sus hijos, su esposo también sigue trabajando, ambos mejorando su casa, ya que con los financiamiento en Afodenic, le ha sido más a corto plazo el avance de la construcción.
Norma con este nuevo préstamo comprara: cerámica para poner en sala y una puerta, dando mejor comodidad y seguridad a su familia. Hoy en día está pasando por momento difícil, ya que su mama falleció, quien dio el amor, y compresión a si como el apoyo, es por tal razón espera darle a sus hijos un techo digno.
texts.en:
Norma continues her small “cajeta” (a soft fudge made from goat's milk) sales, washing, and ironing.  She is always active and helping her children.  Her husband also continues working.  They are both improving their house; with the loan from Afondenic the construction advances more quickly.

With this new loan Norma will buy tile to put down in the living room and a door.  This will make the family more comfortable and safer.

She is now going through a difficult time because her mother died.  Her mother gave her love, understanding, and support.  That is why she hopes to give her children a decent home.

loans.use: to buy tile to put down in the living room and to buy a door.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is married and has five children. She provides grinding of maize. In her shop she also sells maize for grinding to her customers. Her shop is located where her home is. It is in Kisauni, Mombasa, where a lot of people know her. She lives with her husband, who is a businessman. She dreams of seeing her children prosper and develop their own success.

Beatrice often feels that she does not have the money to opportunely respond to all of her customers’ needs. This is her first loan with Yehu Microfinance. She will use the loan to buy spare parts to service her machine and fuel for running it.

With this investment she will have a little bit of everything in her business. This will be an effective solution for her customers. Her biggest dream and challenge is to have two more Posho Mills machines in a good location. That is where she will totally diversify her services, and she will make her business increasingly well known.

loans.use: to buy spare parts to service her machine and fuel for running it.

loans.name: Aliyar

texts.en:
Aliyar is a 39 year old man, IDP (internally displaced person) who lives in Bilasuvar IDP Settlement with his wife and two sons. He is a farmer and has raised seasonal fruits and vegetables for the last 13 years. He chose this business because it is profitable and fresh crops are always in high demand. People use fresh vegetables every day and consider them healthy.  Many national dishes are made of vegetables, like pilau and dolma.  Fresh fruits are served on every table in Azerbaijan families and they also make fresh punches.

Aliyar sells his crops in the BIlasuvar central bazaar. His monthly income is 100 AZN. His wife actively helps him to raise crops.

As his products are in high demand, Aliyar wants to expand his business and produce more fruits and vegetables to cover market demand. For this purpose he has applied for a loan of 1500 AZN. He will buy new garden tools, seeds and fertilizers. This will be his second loan; he has a positive loan history.

loans.use: to buy new garden tools, seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu is a divorced woman. She is the mother of six children, three of whom attend school. For more than three years, she has been a merchant, an activity she began with the aim of helping with the household expenses. She does this by travelling to Mombasa town, where she buys perfumes, clothing, and bags, and selling them in various neighborhoods. Her main customers are women, although she also sells to men.

Currently, her financial indicators show a high turnover of merchandise. This shows a business with considerable potential for growth, even though her greatest challenge is having sufficient working capital to respond with many more products to a market that is waiting to buy them from her.

This is why she is applying for her Kiva loan, her fifth loan from Yehu Microfinance. By means of this loan, she will buy mainly perfume, clothing, and footwear. With this, she will impress her clientele with various fashion designs and original aromas.

loans.use: to buy mainly perfume, clothing, and footwear.

loans.name: Khurmo

texts.en: Khurmo is a woman who realizes her own plans. She is known as a kind, smart, clever, and hardworking woman.  She is also a beginning business woman. For some years, she worked as a seller of gold products in a shop. Now, she wants to organize her own business. Her business will develop day by day because she knows what she is doing. She hasn't any children; she is a widow. In beginning her business, she has nobody to help her. She is asking a loan to buy goods for developing her jewelry business.

loans.use: To buy goods for developing her new business

loans.name: Las Moreñas Group

texts.es: El Banco de emprendimiento LAS MOREÑAS está  compuesto por ocho integrantes todas mujeres,  la presidenta del banco es la Sra. Lorena,  ella tiene 38 años tiene un hijo de la edad de 18 años, su hijo  se encuentra estudiando, La Sra. Lorena vive  en la zona de Mora,   se dedica a la venta de comida en su puesto de venta que se encuentra en la misma zona donde vive,  este préstamo es su primera  secuencia dentro de la institución, la Sra. Lorena va a usar este préstamo para compra de insumos por mayor como papa, arroz, fideo y aceite para la elaboración de sus comidas y así de esta manera incrementar su capital de trabajo,  su razón para solicitar este préstamo es seguir mejorando en su  negocio, la Sra. Lorena va a utilizar los beneficios para seguir comprando insumos y así mejorando sus ingresos, su deseo para su negocio es tener un restaurante y así brindar mayor comodidad a su clientela. La Sra. Lorena es una persona muy trabajadora se siente feliz por la oportunidad brindada a ella ya sus compañeras de grupo ya que en algunos casos mantienen solas a sus familias.
texts.en:
The "Las Morenitas" communal bank is composed of eight members, all women. The chairperson of the bank is Lorena. She is 38, and has an 18-year-old son. Her son is in school. Lorena lives in the Mora area and sells meals at her food stand, located in the same area where she lives. This is her first loan with the institution.

Lorena is going to use this loan to buy ingredients at wholesale, such as potatoes, rice, noodles and cooking oil, for making her meals. In this way she will increase her working capital.

Her reason for applying for this loan is to continue improving her business. Lorena is going to use the profits to keep buying supplies and improving her income. Her wish for her business is to have a restaurant and this way provide greater comfort to her customers.

Lorena is a very hard-working person, and she feels happy about the opportunity offered to her and her fellow group members, as in some cases they are the sole support of their families.

loans.use: To buy ingredients at wholesale such as potatoes, rice, noodles and cooking oil, for making her meals.

loans.name: Leydi Yasenia

texts.es:
Leydi tiene 32 años de edad, es casada y tiene tres hijos. Ella es propietaria y administradora de una pequeña tienda desde hace ocho años. La tienda esta instalada en su propia casa; así no descuida a su familia y es una forma en que ella ayuda a los gastos del hogar. Leydi es muy visionaria ya que ella detecto que en el lugar donde vive no habían tiendas, por esa razón inicio con su negocio. A la vez que quería sentirse útil y que su esposo se sienta orgulloso de ella.

Los productos para su tienda, los compra su esposo, debido a que él trabaja en la distribución de estos productos. Él viaja desde el lugar donde viven hasta la ciudad durante cuarenta minutos en automóvil. 

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar más productos para su tienda. Con el objetivo de fortalecer su negocio, mejorar sus ganancias, para satisfacer las necesidades de su hogar, entre ellos brindarles el estudio a sus hijos.

Con las ganancias que obtenga de la inversión que realizara, ella manifiesta que ahorrara para instalar una crianza de cerdos. Actualmente posee una cerda parindera, pero su deseo es tener una granja de cerdos.
texts.en:
Leydi is 31 years old, married and has three children.  She owns a small store which she has been running for eight years.  The store is located in her own home so that she doesn't have to neglect her family.  This is how she helps towards covering her household expenses.  Leydi is a very visionary woman as she saw that there were no stores where she lives and so started her business.  She also wanted to feel useful and for her husband to be proud of her.

Leydi's husband buys the products for her store because his job is distributing these products.  He travels from their home to the city which takes him 40 minutes by car.

Leydi is requesting a loan from Fundación Campo to buy more products for her store.  Her aim is to strengthen her business, improve her profits and cover her family's needs.  One of these needs is providing her children with an education.

Leydi says that she plans to use the profits that she makes from this investment to save up so that she can start a pig-raising business.  She currently owns one sow but her wish is to own a pig farm.

loans.use: to buy more products for her store

loans.name: Los Pagadores 2012 Group

texts.es: El Banco de emprendimiento LOS PAGADORES 2012 está  compuesto por once integrantes ocho mujeres y tres varones,  la presidenta del banco es la Sra.  Verónica  vive por la zona  de Los Lotes, La presidenta del banco en la foto es la que viste blusa verde claro es la única mujer que se encuentra de pie en la fila de los varones, ella tiene 38 años y dos hijos de las edades de 5 y 8 años, todos ellos en edad escolar, La Sra. verónica se dedica a la venta de salchichas, embutidos de jamón y mortadela  en su puesto de venta que se encuentra en la misma zona donde vive,  este préstamo es su quinta secuencia dentro de la institución, la Sra. Verónica  va a usar este préstamo para compra de salchichas y embutidos por mayor y así de esta manera incrementar su capital de trabajo,  su razón para solicitar este préstamo es seguir mejorando en su  negocio, la Sra. Verónica va a utilizar los beneficios para seguir comprando embutidos y así mejorando sus ingresos, su deseo para su negocio es tener una frial muy surtida y así brindar mayor variedad de productos  a su clientela. La Sra. Veronica es una persona muy trabajadora se siente feliz por la oportunidad brindada a ella ya sus compañeras de grupo ya que en algunos casos mantienen solas a sus familias.
texts.en:
The 'LOS PAGADORES 2012' community bank has eleven members: eight women and three men.  The bank president is Verónica, who lives in Los Lotes.  In the photo, she is the lady wearing a light green top.  She is the only woman standing up in the line of men.  She is 38 years old and has two children who are 8 and 5 years old.  They are both school age.  

Verónica's business is selling sausages, ham and bologna.  She sells these products from a sales location in her neighborhood.  This loan is her fifth from the institution.  Verónica will use her loan to buy sausages and cold cuts wholesale.  This will increase her working capital.  She is requesting the loan so that she can continue improving her business.  Verónica will use the profits she makes to continue buying cold cuts so that she can continue improving her income.  Her wish for her business is to have a very well-stocked store so that she can provide her customers with a wider range of products.  Verónica is a very hard-working person.  She feels happy that she and her fellow group members are receiving this opportunity as many of them support their families on their own.

loans.use: to buy sausages and cold cuts wholesale

loans.name: Hiba

texts.en:
Hiba is a 24-year-old woman, married, and the mother of one son.  She is a conservative person who prefers not to have her photo published online, so her husband appears in her Kiva profile photo.

For the past year, Hiba's husband has had a computer accessories store in the city, in addition to maintaining computers for customers.  This work has been a profitable project and the only source of income for the family, but it also needs more support to cover the family's needs.

Hiba is requesting a 2,000 USD youth loan from FATEN to help her husband cover the costs of purchasing new tools for maintaining computers. This will improve the quality of his work and increase the family's income positively.

loans.use: to purchase new tools for maintaining computers

loans.name: Nver

texts.en:
Nver is a farmer from Tatev village, Armenia. He runs a farm where he raises cows, sheep, and hens. He also grows apple, walnut, and pear trees and cultivates potatoes and beans. Despite such a variety of agricultural activities, the main income Nver receives from the cattle by selling meat, milk, and other agricultural products. Therefore, Nver would like to purchase more cattle and increase his income. With the requested loan amount, he plans to purchase five calves. Such development of cattle husbandry will provide additional income for Nver and his family. 

Nver lives with his wife, two daughters (14 and 7 years old), 12-year-old son, and pensioner mother. Nver's wife and mother support him with agriculture. Nver wishes to provide access to higher education for his children in the future. Current development of agriculture is important for him to have a good background to make his dream come true.

loans.use: to pay for five calves

loans.name: Elvin

texts.en:
Elvin is a 28 year old man who is very friendly and hard working. He is an IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with his wife and two daughters in Bilasuvar IDP Settlement. He is a farmer and has raised seasonal fruits and vegetables for the last 10 years.  Elvin was unemployed and did not have an educational degree.  When he got married he needed a financial resource to support his new family so he started his business. 

Within two years Elvin gained enough skills and experience to run the business, thanks to his father`s experience. He chose this crop business because it is profitable and fresh fruits and vegetables are in high demand. 

People use fresh vegetables every day and consider them healthy.  Many national dishes are made of vegetables, like pilau and dolma.  Fresh fruits are served on every table in Azerbaijan families and also make fresh punch. Elvin usually sells his crops in the central bazaar. His monthly income is 120 AZN.

As his products are in high demand, Elvin wants to expand his business and produce more fruits and vegetables to cover market demand and to increase his monthly income. For this purpose he has applied for a loan of 1000 AZN. He will buy new garden tools, seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: to buy new garden tools, seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Natampash

texts.en:
Natampash is 49 years old and married. He supports a family of 15 people.  He has been a wheat farmer for the last 10 years earning a monthly income of KES 80,000.

He is servicing his fourth loan of KES 90,000 from KADET LTD and this will help him with preparations for the farm and the purchase of inputs.

He hopes to use his anticipated profits to expand his farm and reinvest. His future dreams is to improve the family's living standards and buy more land.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs and prepare the land.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is a conservative person who prefers not to have her photo published online, so her husband appears in her Kiva profile photo, pictured in his store.

Sonia is a 32-year-old young woman, she is married and a mother to two sons and one daughter.

For the past four years, Sonia's husband has been working in purchasing, selling and exchanging gas canisters to customers from public people and institutions, which has been a profitable project and the only source of income to the family.  But he needs more support to cover the family's expenses and cover the costs of work.

Sonia is requesting a 3,000 USD loan from FATEN to help her husband cover the costs of purchasing a number of gas canisters to sell and exchange. This will allow Sonia's husband to expand the scope of his work, improve his business, and increase the family's income, which will offer the family better living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase gas canisters.

loans.name: Efraín

texts.es:
Efraín tiene 43 años de edad, tiene una hija. Él vive con su pequeña hija, desde muy pequeña quedo sola con su papá. Efraín siempre ha trabajo en la agricultura, ya que fue heredado de sus padres. Trabaja muy fuerte desde la una de la mañana. 

Los insumos para realizar sus trabajos, los adquiere en la ciudad más cercana a su casa, que esta a una hora, para ello debe caminar y luego aborda un autobús, ya que en su comunidad no hay servicio de trasporte colectivo. 

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundacion Campo, es para comprar fertilizantes, fungicidas, herbicidas, para el cultivo de maíz y comprar tres quintales de hierro para su oficio de herrador, pues también elabora cumas para trabajar. De esta manera él obtendrá una buena producción para venderla posteriormente a un buen precio y también las cumas. Para brindarle a su hija todo lo necesario para su desarrollo.
texts.en:
Efraín is 43 years old, and he has a daughter.  He lives with his young daughter, who was left alone with her father ever since she was very little.

Efraín has always worked in farming because it was passed on from his parents.  He works very hard starting at one in the morning.
